linkTarget.anchoringText: This western region of the Ivishak is known as the Eileen West End (EWE) and Northwest Eileen (NWE) (see Figs. 1 & 2). [MJB1]Four well pads were constructed to access this area of the field, along with a shared production line system to carry produced fluids back to Prudhoe’s Gathering Center 2 (GC2), one of Prudhoe’s seven large collection and separation facilities. The well pads are W-pad, Z-pad, V-pad, and L-pad. Collectively they are known as the “West End,” and the shared production line is called the EWE LDF (large diameter flowline) (see Fig. 3).

This western region of the Ivishak is known as the Eileen West End (EWE) and Northwest Eileen (NWE) (see Figs. 1 & 2). [MJB1]Four well pads were constructed to access this area of the field, along with a shared production line system to carry produced fluids back to Prudhoe’s Gathering Center 2 (GC2), one of Prudhoe’s seven large collection and separation facilities. The well pads are W-pad, Z-pad, V-pad, and L-pad. Collectively they are known as the “West End,” and the shared production line is called the EWE LDF (large diameter flowline) (see Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Prudhoe subsurface extent, with EWE area of the field at left

formatted-caption.caption-text: Prudhoe subsurface extent, with EWE area of the field at left

linkTarget.anchoringText: This western region of the Ivishak is known as the Eileen West End (EWE) and Northwest Eileen (NWE) (see Figs. 1 & 2). [MJB1]Four well pads were constructed to access this area of the field, along with a shared production line system to carry produced fluids back to Prudhoe’s Gathering Center 2 (GC2), one of Prudhoe’s seven large collection and separation facilities. The well pads are W-pad, Z-pad, V-pad, and L-pad. Collectively they are known as the “West End,” and the shared production line is called the EWE LDF (large diameter flowline) (see Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: EWE Large Diameter Flowline and “tributary” flowlines of West End

formatted-caption.caption-text: EWE Large Diameter Flowline and “tributary” flowlines of West End

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition to the mixture velocity limitation of the EWE line, the well stock faces a second constraint due to supply pressure problems experienced from a shared and very long gas lift supply line. From GC2, this line stretches a total of 81,000 ft (15 miles) out to L-pad (see Fig. 4), supplying lift gas to the three other West End pads along the way. Additionally, the line’s diameter reduces along its length, beginning at just over 10-in internal diameter (ID) and ending at just under 8-in ID.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: West End gas lift supply line

formatted-caption.caption-text: West End gas lift supply line

linkTarget.anchoringText: The segments are connected to represent the actual pipeline configuration of the field. It is not necessary from a mathematical solution perspective to have the end model look exactly as the field looks from a bird’s eye point of view, but it has been found it is much more intuitive to work with and understand a model if it has the overall general shape and arrangement as the actual surface network. This is especially true if the system to be modelled is a large one. Nodes are placed to connect the segments together and to act as computation points for the program when it solves for pressures and flow rates. Nodes are also placed at the most upstream points, where individual wells feed into the surface system (see Figs 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9).

The segments are connected to represent the actual pipeline configuration of the field. It is not necessary from a mathematical solution perspective to have the end model look exactly as the field looks from a bird’s eye point of view, but it has been found it is much more intuitive to work with and understand a model if it has the overall general shape and arrangement as the actual surface network. Once the dedicated gas lift system model was complete (see Figs 10, 11, 12, 13, and 14)itwas incorporated into and synchronised with the production model so that the calculated casing pressures from the modelled gas lift injection system would be passed to the wells in the modelled production system. It was imperative to ensure the wells could respond appropriately to these casing pressures. Gas lift valve depths were introduced into each individual nodal analysis well model, and a casing pressure variable was included with the other VLP variables of WHP, gas lift rate, WC, and GOR.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Gas lift Injection Model layout, West End

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas lift Injection Model layout, West End
